I don't disagree at all with what you're saying - just pointing out that at most universities, you now have a situation where in STEM degree programs, tenured profs are mostly teaching to grad students and doing business-funded research, and across the way, liberal_arts tenured exist in niche areas that are somewhat funded by grants, but also subsidized by the U (via all students' tuition).

For the vast majority of students just wanting to get a common undergrad degree, the clearest path to cost reduction is to essentially get rid of the people not directly teaching all the undergrads today.  Not saying that[.] a good situation for profs or the university system, but community colleges could easily be turned into existing 4-year programs at a much lower cost.

Maybe you'd have a situation in which fewer universities have niche programs, like you have a super-group of latin scholars at one U ere everyone interested in that now goes, as opposed to having a few latin scholars at every U.  Maybe one of your state schools becomes the "teaching college" while another one focuses on sciences, etc.  There[.] certainly a lot of benefit from having so many programs at the same school academically, however it seems like for most students in common degress, they end up subsidizing that benefit for a relatively few number of cross-program students.
